10.text: A wise son makes his father glad: but a foolish son is a grief to his mother.
A wise son is saved from heat: but a lawless son is blighted of the winds in harvest.
A wise man in heart will receive commandments; but he that is unguarded in his lips shall be overthrown in his perverseness.
A fool does mischief in . laughter. sport; but wisdom brings forth prudence for a man.

11.text: A righteous man escapes from a snare, and the ungodly man is delivered up in his place.
A man void of understanding sneers at his fellow citizens: but a sensible man is quiet.
A bad man does harm wherever he meets a just man: and he hates the sound of safety.

A gracious wife §§ . raises. brings glory to her husband: but a woman hating righteousness is a theme of dishonour. slothful come to want: but the *** . manly. diligent support themselves with wealth.
A merciful man does good to his own soul: but the merciless destroys his own body.
A righteous son is born for life: but the persecution of the ungodly ends in death.

12.text: A man shall not prosper by wickedness; but the roots of the righteous shall not be taken up.
A virtuous woman is a crown to her husband; but as a worm in wood, so a bad woman destroys her husband.
A righteous man has pity for the lives of his cattle; but the bowels of the ungodly are unmerciful.
A fool declares his wrath the same day; but a prudent man hides his own disgrace.
A righteous man declares the open truth; but an unjust witness is deceitful.
A terrible word troubles the heart of a righteous man; but a good message rejoices him.
A just arbitrator shall be his own friend; but mischief shall pursue sinners; and the way of ungodly men shall lead them astray.
A deceitful man shall catch no game; but a . pure. blameless man is a precious possession.

13.text: A wise son is obedient to his father: but a disobedient son will be destroyed.
A good man shall eat of the fruits of righteousness: but the lives of transgressors shall perish before their time.
A righteous man hates an unjust word: but an ungodly man is ashamed, and will have no confidence. * for text shown as: preserves the simple in the way, but sin makes worthless the ungodly.
A man's own wealth is the ransom of his life: but the poor , comes not in for. endures not threatening.
A bad man does evil with insolence: but they that are judges of themselves are wise.
A rash king shall fall into mischief: but a wise messenger shall deliver him.
A good man shall inherit children's children; and the wealth of ungodly men is laid up for the just.
A just man eats and satisfies his soul: but the souls of the ungodly are in want. <

14.text: A faithful witness does not lie; but an unjust witness kindles falsehoods.
A § . bold-hearted. stout-hearted man shall be filled with his own ways; and a good man with his own thoughts.
A wise man fears, and departs from evil; but the fool trusts in himself, and joins himself with the transgressor.
A passionate man acts inconsiderately; but a sensible man bears up under many things.
A prudent man is the crown of the wise: but the occupation of fools is evil.
A faithful witness shall deliver a soul from evil: but a deceitful man kindles falsehoods.
A man slow to wrath abounds in wisdom: but a man of impatient spirit is very foolish.
A meek-spirited man is a healer of the heart: but a sensitive heart is a corruption of the bones.

15.text: A fool scorns his father's instruction: but he that keeps his commandments is more prudent. abounding righteousness is great strength: but the ungodly shall . with the roots wholly torn up. utterly perish from the earth.
A wise son gladdens his father; but a foolish son sneers at his mother.
A bad man will by no means ** , obey. attend to counsel; neither will he say anything seasonable, or good for the common weal .

16.text: A man who labours, labours for himself, and drives from him his own ruin.
A perverse man spreads mischief, and will kindle a torch of deceit with mischiefs; and he separates friends.
A transgressor tries to ensnare friends, and leads them in ways that are not good.
A man slow to anger is better than a strong man ; and he that governs his temper better than he that takes a city.

17.text: A wise servant shall have rule over foolish masters, and shall divide portions among brethren.
A bad man hearkens to the tongue of transgressors: but a righteous man attends not to false lips.
A threat breaks down the heart of a wise man; but a fool, though scourged, understands not.
A foolish man applauds and rejoices over himself, as he also that becomes surety would make himself responsible for his own friends.
A lover of sin rejoices in strifes;
A glad heart promotes health; but the bones of a sorrowful man dry up.
A foolish son is a cause of anger to his father, and grief to her that bore him.

18.text: A man who wishes to separate from friends seeks excuses; but at all times he will be liable to reproach.
A senseless man feels no need of wisdom, for he is rather led by folly.
A word in the heart of a man is a deep water, and a river and fountain of life spring forth.
A fool's mouth is ruin to him, and his lips are a snare to his soul.
A man who helps not himself by his labour is brother of him that ruins himself.
A wise servant calms a man's anger; but who can endure a faint-hearted man?
A righteous man accuses himself at the beginning of his speech, but . . ult. and margin, with
A silent man quells strifes, and determines between great powers.
A brother helped by a brother is as a strong and high city; and is as strong as a well -founded palace.
A man fills his belly with the fruits of his mouth; and he shall be satisfied with the fruits of his lips.

19.text: A false witness shall not be unpunished, and he that accuses unjustly shall not escape.
A false witness shall not be unpunished; and whosoever shall kindle mischief shall perish by it.
A merciful man is long-suffering; and his * . boasting comes upon. triumph overtakes transgressors.
A foolish son is a disgrace to his father: vows paid out of the hire of a harlot are not pure.
A malicious man shall be severely punished, and if he commit injury, he shall also lose his life.
A son who ceases to attend to the instruction of a father will cherish evil designs.

20.text: A sluggard when reproached is not ashamed: so also he who borrows corn in harvest.
A man is valuable, and a merciful man precious: but it is hard to find a faithful man.
A large and small weight, and * . double. divers measures, are even both of them unclean before the ; and so is he that makes them.
A youth when in company with a godly man, will be restrained in his devices, and then his way will be straight.
A double weight is an abomination to the ; and a deceitful balance is not good in his sight.
A man's goings are directed of the : how then can a mortal understand his ways?
A wise king utterly crushes the ungodly, and will bring a wheel upon them.

21.text: A high-minded man is stout-hearted in his pride; and the lamp of the wicked is sin.
A righteous man understands the hearts of the ungodly: and despises the ungodly for their wickedness.
A secret gift calms anger: but he that forbears to give stirs up strong wrath.
A man that wanders out of the way of righteousness, shall rest in the congregation of . . see . on
A poor man loves mirth, loving wine and oil in abundance;
A desirable treasure will rest on the mouth of the wise; but foolish men will swallow it up.
A wise man assaults strong cities, and demolishes the fortress in which the ungodly trusted.
A bold and self-willed and insolent man is called a pest: and he that remembers injuries is a transgressor.
A false witness shall perish; but an obedient man will speak cautiously.
A horse is prepared for the day of battle; but help is of the . <

22.text: A fair name is better than much wealth, and good favour is above silver and gold.

23.text: A righteous father brings up his children well; and his soul rejoices over a wise son.

24.text: A house is built by wisdom, and is set up by understanding.
A wise man is better than a strong man; and a man who has prudence than a large estate.
A foolish man is like a farm, and a senseless man is like a vineyard.
I reflected, I looked that I might receive instruction.
A lion's whelp, stronger than all other beasts, which turns not away, nor fears any beast;

26.text: I have seen a man who seemed . by. to himself to be wise; but a fool had more hope than he.
A sluggard when sent on a journey says, is a lion in the ways, and there are murderers in the streets.
A sluggard having hid his hand in his bosom, will not be able to bring it up to his mouth.
A sluggard seems to himself wiser than one who § . most satisfactorily brings back a message.
A hearth for coals, and wood for fire; and a railing man for the tumult of strife.
A weeping enemy promises all things with his lips, but in his heart he contrives deceit.
A lying tongue hates the truth; and an unguarded mouth causes tumults. <

27.text: A stone is heavy, and sand cumbersome; but a fool's wrath is heavier than both.
A full soul scorns honeycombs; but to a hungry soul even bitter things appear sweet.
A wise man, when evils are approaching, hides himself; but fools pass on, and will be punished.

28.text: A bold man oppresses the poor by ungodly deeds. an impetuous and unprofitable rain,
A poor man walking in truth is better than a rich liar.
A wise son keeps the law: but he that keeps up debauchery dishonours his father.
A rich man is wise in his own conceit; but an intelligent poor man will condemn him.
A hungry lion and a thirsty wolf is he , who, being poor, rules over a poor nation.
A king in need of revenues is a great oppressor: but he that hates injustice shall live a long time.
A man worthy of credit shall be much blessed: but the wicked shall not be unpunished.

29.text: A reprover is better than a stiff-necked man: for when the latter is suddenly set on fire, there shall be no remedy.
A righteous king establishes a country: but a transgressor destroys it .
A great snare is spread for a sinner: but the righteous shall be in joy and gladness.
A righteous man knows how to judge for the poor: but the ungodly understands not knowledge; and the poor man has not an understanding mind.
A wise man shall judge nations: but a worthless man being angry laughs and fears not.
A fool utters all his mind: but the wise reserves his in part.
A stubborn servant will not be reproved by words: for even if he understand, still he will not obey.
A furious man stirs up strife, and a passionate man digs up sin.
A righteous man is an abomination to an unrighteous man, and the direct way is an abomination to the sinner. <

1.text: A generation goes, and a generation comes: but the earth stands for ever.
I the was king over in .
I applied my heart to seek out and examine by wisdom concerning all things that are done under heaven, for has given to the sons of men an evil trouble to be troubled therewith.
I beheld all the works that were wrought under the sun; and, behold, all were vanity and waywardness of spirit.
I spoke in my heart, saying, , I am increased, and have acquired wisdom beyond all who were before me in : also I applied my heart to know wisdom and knowledge.

2.text: I said in my heart, now, I will prove thee with mirth, and behold thou good: and, behold, this is also vanity.
I said to laughter, : and to mirth, doest thou this?

I examined whether my heart would excite my flesh as with wine, (though my heart guided me in wisdom,) and I desired to lay hold of mirth, until I should see of what kind is the good to the sons of men, which they should do under the sun all the days of their life.
I enlarged my work; I built me houses; I planted me vineyards.
I made me gardens and orchards, and planted in them every kind of fruit-tree.
I made me pools of water, to water from them the timber-bearing wood.
I got servants and maidens, and servants were born to me in the house: also I had abundant possession of flocks and herds, beyond all who were before me in .

I collected for myself both silver and gold also, and the peculiar treasures of kings and provinces: I procured me singing men and singing women, and delights of the sons of men, a butler and female cupbearers.
I became great, and advanced beyond all that were before me in : also my wisdom was established to me.
I looked on all my works which my hands had wrought, and on my labour which I laboured to perform: and, behold, all was vanity and waywardness of spirit, and there is no advantage under the sun.
I looked on to see wisdom, and madness, and folly: for who is the man who will follow after counsel, in all things wherein he employs it?
I saw that wisdom excels folly, as much as light excels darkness.

I said in my heart, the event of the fool is, so shall it be to me, even to me; and to what purpose have I gained wisdom? I said moreover in my heart, is also vanity, because the fool speaks of his abundance.
I hated life; because the work that was wrought under the sun was evil before me: for all is vanity and waywardness of spirit.
I hated the whole of my labour which I took under the sun; because I must leave it to the man who will come after me.
I went about to dismiss from my heart all my labour wherein I had laboured under the sun.
A man has nothing really good to eat, and to drink, and to shew his soul as good in his trouble. also I saw, that it is from the hand of .

3.text: A time of birth, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up what has been planted;
I have seen all the trouble, which has given to the sons of men to be troubled with.
I know that there is no good in them, except for a man to rejoice, and to do good in his life.
I know that whatsoever things has done, they shall be for ever: it is impossible to add to it, and it is impossible to take away from it: and has done it , that men may fear before him.
I said in my heart, will judge the righteous and the ungodly: for there is a time there for every action and for every work.
I said in my heart, concerning the speech of the sons of man, will judge them, and that to shew that they are beasts.
I saw that there was no good, but that wherein a man shall rejoice in his works, for it is his portion, for who shall bring him to see any thing of that which shall be after him? ublic

4.text: I returned, and saw all the oppressions that were done under the sun: and behold the tear of the oppressed, and they had no comforter; and on the side of them that oppressed them was power; but they had no comforter:
I saw all labour, and all the diligent work, that this is a man's envy from his neighbour. is also vanity and waywardness of spirit.
I returned, and saw vanity under the sun.
I beheld all the living who were walking under the sun, with the second youth who shall stand up in each one's place.

7.text: A good name is better than good oil; and the day of death than the day of birth.
I have seen all things in the days of my vanity: there is a just man perishing in his justice, and there is an ungodly man remaining in his wickedness.
I and my heart went round about to know, and to examine, and to seek wisdom, and the account of things , and to know the folly and trouble and madness of the ungodly man.

I find her to be , and I will pronounce to be more bitter than death the woman which is a snare, and her heart nets, who has a band in her hands: he that is good in the sight of shall be delivered from her; but the sinner shall be caught by her.

8.text: A man's wisdom will lighten his countenance; but a man of shameless countenance will be hated.
I saw all this, and I applied my heart to every work that has been done under the sun; all the things wherein man has power over man to afflict him.

I praised mirth, because there is no good for a man under the sun, but to eat, and drink, and be merry: and this shall attend him in his labour all the days of his life, which has given him under the sun.
I set my heart to know wisdom, and to perceive the trouble that was wrought upon the earth: for there is that neither by day nor night sees sleep with his eyes.

I beheld all the works of , that a man shall not be able to discover the work which is wrought under the sun; whatsoever things a man shall endeavour to seek, however a man may labour to seek it, yet he shall not find it; yea, how much soever a wise man may speak of knowing it, he shall not be able to find it: for I applied all this to my heart, and my heart has seen all this. ublic

9.text: I saw that the righteous, and the wise, and their works, are in the hand of : yea, there is no man that knows either love or hatred, though all are before their face.

I returned, and saw under the sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, nor yet bread to the wise, nor yet wealth to men of understanding, nor yet favour to men of knowledge; for time and chance will happen to them all.
I also saw to be wisdom under the sun, and it is great before me:
I said, is better than power: yet the wisdom of the poor man is set at nought, and his words not listened to.

10.text: A wise man's heart is at his right hand; but a fool's heart at his left.
I have seen servants upon horses, and princes walking as servants on the earth.
A fool moreover multiplies words: man knows not what has been, nor what will be: who shall tell him what will come after him?

2.text: I am a flower of the plain, a lily of the valleys.

I have charged you, O daughters of , by the powers and by the virtues of the field, that ye rouse not nor awake my love, until he please.

5.text: I sleep, but my heart is awake: the voice of my kinsman knocks at the door, saying , , open to me, my companion, my sister, my dove, my perfect one: for my head is filled with dew, and my locks with the drops of the night.

I rose up to open to my kinsman; my hands dropped myrrh, my fingers choice myrrh, on the handles of the lock.

I have charged you, O daughters of , by the powers and the virtues of the field: if ye should find my kinsman, what are ye to say to him? I am wounded with love.

6.text: I am my kinsman's, and my kinsman is mine, who feeds among the lilies.

I am my kinsman's, and his desire is toward me.

8.text: I would that thou, O my kinsman, wert he that sucked the breasts of my mother; when I found thee without, I would kiss thee; yea, they should not despise me.
I would take thee, I would bring thee into my mother's house, and into the chamber of her that conceived me; I would make thee to drink of spiced wine, of the juice of my pomegranates.
I have charged you, ye daughters of , by the virtues of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love, until he please.
I am a wall, and my breasts are as towers; I was in their eyes as one that found peace.

1.text: I will bring my hand upon thee, and purge thee . to pureness. completely, and I will destroy the rebellious, and will take away from thee all transgressors.

I will forsake my vineyard; and it shall not be pruned, nor dug, and thorns shall come up upon it as on barren land; and I will command the clouds to rain no rain upon it.

42.text: A bruised reed shall he not break, and smoking flax shall he not quench; but he shall bring forth judgment to truth.
I the have called thee in righteousness, and will hold thine hand, and will strengthen thee: and I have given thee for the covenant of a race, for a light of the ;

I have been silent: shall I also always be silent and forbear? I have endured like a travailing woman : I will now amaze and wither at once.
I will make desolate mountains and hills, and will dry up all their grass; and I will make the rivers islands, and dry up the pools.

I will bring the blind by a way that they knew not, and I will cause them to tread paths which they have not known: I will turn darkness into light for them, and crooked things into straight. things will I do, and will not forsake them.

I beheld, and the people were spoiled and plundered: for there is a snare in the secret chambers everywhere, and in the houses also, where they have hidden them: they became a spoil, and there was no one that delivered the prey, and there was none who said, .

I am the , your , who have appointed for your king.

44.text: I will give water to the thirsty that walk in a dry land: I will put my upon thy seed, and my blessings upon thy children:

45.text: I will go before thee, and will level mountains: I will break to pieces brazen doors, and will burst iron bars.

47.text: I have been provoked with my people; thou hast defiled mine inheritance: I gave them into thy hand, but thou didst not extend mercy to them: thou madest the yoke of the aged man very heavy,

48.text: I know that thou art stubborn, and thy neck is an iron sinew, and thy forehead brazen.

I told thee * . the ancient things before they came. of old what should be before it came upon thee; I made it known to thee, lest thou shouldest say, idols have done it for me; and shouldest say, graven and molten images have commanded me.
I have spoken, I have called, I have brought him, and made his way prosperous.

49.text: I said, I have laboured in vain, I have given my strength for vanity and for nothing: therefore is my judgment with the , and my labour before my .

50.text: I will clothe the sky with darkness, and will make its covering as sackcloth.
I gave my back to scourges, and my cheeks to blows; and I turned not away my face from the shame of spitting:

51.text: I, even I, am he that comforts thee: consider who thou art, that thou wast afraid of mortal man, and of the son of man, who are withered as grass.
I will put my words into thy mouth, and I will shelter thee under the shadow of mine hand, with which I fixed the sky, and founded the earth: and the shall say to , art my people.

I will give it into the hands of them that injured thee, and them that afflicted thee; who said to thy soul, down, that we may pass over: and thou didst level thy body with the ground to them passing by without. <

4.text: I said, O sovereign , verily thou hast greatly deceived this people and , saying, shall be peace; whereas behold, the sword has reached even to their soul.

I am pained in my bowels, my bowels, and the sensitive powers of my heart; my soul is in great commotion, my heart is torn: I will not be silent, for my soul has heard the sound of a trumpet, the cry of war, and of distress: it calls on destruction;
I looked upon the earth, and, behold, it was not; and to the sky, and there was no light in it.
I beheld the mountains, and they trembled, and I saw all the hills in commotion.
I looked, and, behold, there was no man, and all the birds of the sky were scared.
I saw, and, behold, was desert, and all the cities were burnt with fire at the presence of the , and at the presence of his fierce anger they were utterly destroyed.

I have heard thy groaning as the voice of a woman in travail, as of her that brings forth her first child; the voice of the daughter of shall fail through weakness, and she shall lose the strength of her hands, saying , is me! for my soul faints because of the slain. ublic

5.text: O , thine eyes are upon faithfulness: thou hast scourged them, but they have not grieved; thou hast consumed them; but they would not receive correction: they have made their faces harder than a rock; and they would not return.
I said, may be they are poor; for they are weak, for they know not the way of the , or the judgment of .
I will go to the rich men, and will speak to them; for they have known the way of the , and the judgment of : but, behold, with one consent they have broken the yoke, they have burst the bonds.

I have set watchmen over you, saying , ye the sound of the trumpet. they said, will not hear it .

I have caused thee to be tried among tried nations, and thou shalt know me when I have tried their way.

7.text: I will cast you out of my sight, as I cast away your brethren, all the seed of .
I spoke not to your fathers, and commanded them not in the day wherein I brought them up out of the land of , concerning whole-burnt-offerings and sacrifice:

I will remove the inhabitants of , and make it a dwelling-place of dragons; and I will utterly waste the cities of , so that they shall not be inhabited.

10.text: I know, O , that man's way is not his own; neither shall a man go, and direct his going.

11.text: O , teach me, and I shall know: then I saw their practices.

I as an innocent lamb led to the slaughter, knew not: against me they devised an evil device, saying, and let us put wood into his bread, and let us utterly destroy him from off the land of the living, and let his name not be remembered any more.
O , that judgest righteously, trying the reins and hearts, let me see thy vengeance taken upon them, for to thee I have declared my cause.

12.text: I have forsaken mine house, I have left mine heritage; I have given my beloved one into the hands of her enemies.

13.text: I procured the girdle according to the word of the , and put it about my loins.
I went, and hid it by the , as the commanded me.
I went to the river , and dug, and took the girdle out of the place where I had buried it: and, behold, it was rotten, utterly good for nothing.
I will scatter them a man and his brother, and their fathers and their sons together: I will not have compassion, saith the , and I will not spare, neither will I pity to save them from destruction.
I scattered them as sticks carried by the wind into the wilderness.
I also will expose thy skirts upon thy face, and thy shame shall be seen;

14.text: O , thou art the hope of , and deliverest us in time of troubles; why art thou become as a sojourner upon the land, or as one born in the land, yet turning aside for a resting-place?
I said, O ever living ! behold, their prophets prophesy, and say, shall not see a sword, nor shall famine be among you; for I will give truth and peace on the land, and in this place.
I go forth into the plain, then behold the slain by the sword! and if I enter into the city, then behold the distress of famine! for priest and prophet have gone to a land which they knew not.

15.text: I will punish them with four kinds of death , saith the , the sword to slay, and the dogs to tear, and the wild beasts of the earth, and the birds of the sky to devour and destroy.
I will deliver them up for distress to all the kingdoms of the earth, because of son of king of , for all that he did in .
I will completely scatter them; in the gates of my people they are bereaved of children: they have destroyed my people because of their iniquities.
I will enslave thee to thine enemies round about, in a land which thou hast not known; for a fire has been kindled out of my wrath; it shall burn upon you.
O , remember me, and visit me, and vindicate me before them that persecute me; do not bear long with them; know how I have met with reproach for thy sake, from those who set at nought thy words;
I have not sat in the assembly of them as they mocked, but I feared because of thy power: I sat alone, for I was filled with bitterness.
I will make thee to this people as a strong brazen wall; and they shall fight against thee, but they shall by no means prevail against thee;

16.text: I will recompense their mischiefs doubly, and their sins, whereby they have profaned my land with the carcases of their abominations, and with their iniquities, whereby they have trespassed against mine inheritance.

O , thou art my strength, and mine help, and my refuge in days of evil: to thee the shall come from the end of the earth, and shall say, vain were the idols which our fathers procured to themselves, and there is no help in them.

17.text: I the try the hearts, and prove the reins, to give to every one according to his ways, and according to the fruits of his devices.
O , the hope of , let all that have left thee be ashamed, let them that have revolted be written on the earth, because they have forsaken the fountain of life, the .
I have not been weary of following thee, nor have I desired the day of man; thou knowest; the words that proceed out of my lips are before thy face.

18.text: I went down to the potter's house, and behold, he was making a vessel on the stones.
I not be able, O house of , to do to you as this potter? behold, as the clay of the potter are ye in my hands.
I shall pronounce a decree upon a nation, or upon a kingdom, to cut them off, and to destroy them ;
I will scatter them before their enemies like an east wind; I will shew them the day of their destruction.

19.text: I will destroy the counsel of and the counsel of in this place; and I will cast them down with the sword before their enemies, and by the hands of them that seek their lives: and I will give their dead bodies for food to the birds of the sky and to the wild beasts of the earth.
I will bring this city to desolation and make it a hissing; every one that passes by it shall scowl, and hiss because of all her plague.

20.text: I will give all the strength of this city, and all the labours of it, and all the treasures of the king of , into the hands of his enemies, and they shall bring them to .
I will laugh with my bitter speech, I will call upon rebellion and misery: for the word of the is become a reproach to me and a mockery all my days.
I said, I will by no means name the name of the , and I will no more at all speak in his name. it was as burning fire flaming in my bones, and I am utterly weakened on all sides, and cannot bear up .

I have heard the reproach of many gathering round, saying , ye, and let us conspire together against him, even all his friends: watch his intentions, if perhaps he shall be deceived, and we shall prevail against him, and we shall be avenged on him.
O , that provest just deeds , understanding the reins and hearts, let me see thy vengeance upon them: for to thee I have revealed my cause.

21.text: I will fight against you with an outstretched hand and with a strong arm, with wrath and great anger.
I will smite all the dwellers in this city, both men and cattle, with grievous pestilence: and they shall die.

22.text: I spoke to thee on occasion of thy trespass, but thou saidst, I will not hearken. has been thy way from thy youth, thou hast not hearkened to my voice.
O thou that dwellest in , making thy nest in the cedars, thou shalt groan heavily, when pangs as of a travailing woman are come upon thee.

23.text: I will gather in the remnant of my people in every land, whither I have driven them out, and will set them in their pasture; and they shall increase and be multiplied.
I will raise up shepherds to them, who shall feed them: and they shall fear no more, nor be alarmed, saith the .
I sent not the prophets, yet they ran: neither spoke I to them, yet they prophesied.
I am a nigh at hand, saith the , and not a afar off.

24.text: I will fix mine eyes upon them for good, and I will restore them into this land for good: and I will build them up, and not pull them down; and I will plant them, and not pluck them up.
I will give them a heart to know me, that I am the : and they shall be to me a people, and I will be to them a : for they shall turn to me with all their heart.

I will cause them to be dispersed into all the kingdoms of the earth, and they shall be for a reproach, and a proverb, and an object of hatred, and a curse, in every place whither I have driven them out.

34.text: I have made the earth by my great power, and with my high arm, and I will give it to whomsoever it shall seem good in mine eyes.

I will appear to you:

38.text: I will build thee, and thou shalt be built, O virgin of : thou shalt yet take thy timbrel, and go forth with the party of them that make merry.
I will expand and cheer with wine the soul of the priests the sons of , and my people shall be satisfied with my good things: thus saith the .
A voice was heard in , of lamentation, and of weeping, and wailing; would not cease weeping for her children, because they are not.
I have heard the sound of lamenting, and saying , hast chastened me, and I was chastened; I as a calf was not willingly taught: turn thou me, and I shall turn; for thou art the my .
I have saturated every thirsting soul, and filled every hungry soul.
I awaked, and beheld; and my sleep was sweet to me.

39.text: I bought the field of the son of my father's brother, and I weighed him seventeen shekels of silver.
I wrote it in a book, and sealed it , and took the testimony of witnesses, and weighed the money in the balance.
I took the book of the purchase that was sealed;
I charged in their presence, saying, saith the ;
I prayed to the after I had given the book of the purchase to the son of , saying,
O ever living ! thou hast made the heaven and the earth by thy great power, and with thy high and lofty arm: nothing can be hidden from thee.
I am the , the of all flesh: shall anything be hidden from me!
I will give them another way, and another heart, to fear me continually, and that for good to them and their children after them.
I will make with them an everlasting covenant, which I will by no means turn away from them, and I will put my fear into their heart, that they may not depart from me.
I will visit them to do them good, and I will plant them in this land in faithfulness, and with all my heart, and with all my soul.

40.text: I will turn the captivity of , and the captivity of , and will build them, even as before.
I will cleanse them from all their iniquities, whereby they have sinned against me, and will not remember their sins, whereby they have sinned against me, and revolted from me.

41.text: I will give the men that have transgressed my covenant, who have not kept my covenant, which they made before me, the calf which they prepared to sacrifice with it,
I will even give them to their enemies, and their carcases shall be food for the birds of the sky and for the wild beasts of the earth.
I will give king of , and their princes, into the hands of their enemies, and the host of the king of shall come upon them that run away from them.

42.text: I brought forth the son of the son of , and his brethren, and his sons, and all the family of the ;
I set before them a jar of wine, and cups, and I said, ye wine.

I sent to you my servants the prophets, saying, ye every one from his evil way, and amend your practices, and go not after other gods to serve them, and ye shall dwell upon the land which I gave to you and to your fathers: but ye inclined not your ears, and hearkened not.

43.text: I will visit him, and his family, and his servants: and I will bring upon him, and upon the inhabitants of , and upon the land of , all the evils which I spoke of to them; and they hearkened not.

46.text: I will save thee in that day, and I will by no means deliver thee into the hands of the men before whom thou art afraid.
I will surely save thee, and thou shalt by no means fall by the sword; and thou shalt find thy life, because thou didst trust in me, saith the . ublic

49.text: I will grant you mercy, and pity you, and will restore you to your land.

51.text: I sent to you my servants the prophets early in the morning, and I sent, saying, not ye this abominable thing which I hate.
I will visit them that dwell in the land of , as I have visited , with sword and with famine:
I have watched over them, to hurt them, and not to do them good: and all the dwelling in the land of shall perish by sword and by famine, until they are utterly consumed.

3.text: I became a laughing-stock to all my people; and their song all the day.

1.text: I looked, and, behold, a sweeping wind came from the north, and a great cloud on it, and there was brightness round about it, and gleaming fire, and in the midst of it as it were the appearance of amber in the midst of the fire, and brightness in it.
I looked, and, behold, the four had each one wheel on the ground near the living creatures.
I heard the sound of their wings when they went, as the sound of much water: and when they stood, their wings were let down.

I saw as it were the resemblance of amber from the appearance of the loins and upwards, and from the appearance of the loins and under I saw an appearance of fire, and the brightness thereof round about.

2.text: I looked, and behold, a hand stretched out to me, and in it a volume of a book.

3.text: I perceived the sound of the wings of the living creatures clapping one to the other, and the sound of the wheels was near them, and the sound of the earthquake.
I passed through the air and came into the captivity, and went round to them that dwelt by the river of who were there; and I sat there seven days, conversant in the midst of them.
I have made thee a watchman to the house of ; and thou shalt hear a word of my mouth, and shalt threaten them from me.

I say to the wicked, shalt surely die; and thou hast not warned him, to give warning to the wicked, to turn from his ways, that he should live; that wicked man shall die in his iniquity; but his blood will I require at thy hand.
I arose, and went forth to the plain: and, behold, the glory of the stood there, according to the vision, and according to the glory of the , which I saw by the river of : and I fell on my face.
I will bind thy tongue, and thou shalt be dumb, and shalt not be to them a reprover: because it is a provoking house.

4.text: I have appointed thee their iniquities for a number of days, for a hundred and ninety days: so thou shalt bear the iniquities of the house of .

I said, so, of : surely my soul has not been defiled with uncleanness; nor have I eaten that which died of itself or was torn of beasts from my birth until now; neither has any corrupt flesh entered into my mouth.

5.text: A fourth part thou shalt burn in the fire in the midst of the city, at the fulfilment of the days of the siege: and thou shalt take a fourth part, and burn it up in the midst of it: and a fourth part thou shalt cut with a sword round about it: and a fourth part thou shalt scatter to the wind; and I will draw out a sword after them.
I will do in thee things which I have not done, and the like of which I will not do again, for all thine abominations.

A fourth part of thee shall be cut off by pestilence, and a fourth part of thee shall be consumed in the midst of thee with famine: and as for another fourth part of thee, I will scatter them to every wind; and a fourth part of thee shall fall by the sword round about thee, and I will draw out a sword after them.
I will make thee desolate, and thy daughters round about thee, in the sight of every one that passes through.

I will send forth against thee famine and evil beasts, and I will take vengeance upon thee; and pestilence and blood shall pass through upon thee; and I will bring a sword upon thee round about. I the have spoken. ublic

6.text: I will scatter your bones round about your altars,
I will stretch out my hand against them, and I will make the land desolate and ruined from the wilderness of , in all their habitations: and ye shall know that I am the . ublic

7.text: I will pour out mine anger upon thee near at hand, and I will accomplish my wrath on thee: and I will judge thee for thy ways, and recompense upon thee all thine abominations.
I will deliver them into the hands of strangers to make them a prey, and to the pests of the earth for a spoil; and they shall profane them.
I will turn away my face from them, and they shall defile my charge, and shall go in to them unguardedly, and profane them.
I will turn back the boasting of their strength; and their holy things shall be defiled.

8.text: I looked, and, behold, the likeness of a man: from his loins and downwards there was fire, and from his loins upwards there was as the appearance of amber.
I went in and looked; and beheld vain abominations, and all the idols of the house of , portrayed upon them round about.

10.text: I looked, and, behold, over the firmament that was above the head of the cherubs there was a likeness of a throne over them, as a sapphire stone.
I saw the cherubs having the likeness of men's hands under their wings.
I saw, and behold, four wheels stood by the cherubs, one wheel by each cherub: and the appearance of the wheels was as the appearance of a carbuncle stone.

11.text: I will bring you forth out of the midst of it, and will deliver you into the hands of strangers, and will execute judgments among you.
I will give them another heart, and will put a new spirit within them; and will extract the heart of stone from their flesh, and give them a heart of flesh:
I spoke to the captivity all the words of the which he had shewed me. ublic

12.text: I did thus according to all that he commanded me; and I carried forth my baggage for captivity by day, and in the evening I dug through the wall for myself, and went out secretly; I was taken up on men's shoulders before them.
I will spread out my net upon him, and he shall be caught in my toils: and I will bring him to to the land of the ; but he shall not see it, though he shall die there.
I will scatter to every wind all his assistants round about him, and all that help him; and I will draw out a sword after them.

I will leave of them a few men in number spared from the sword, and from famine, and from pestilence; that they may declare all their iniquities among the nations whither they have gone; and they shall know that I am the .
I the will speak my words; I will speak and perform them , and will no more delay, for in your days, O provoking house, I will speak the word, and will perform it , saith the .

13.text: I will stretch forth my hand against the prophets that see false visions , and those that utter vanities: they shall not partake of the instruction of my people, neither shall they be written in the roll of the house of , and they shall not enter into the land of ; and they shall know that I am the .

I will break down the wall which ye have plastered, and it shall fall; and I will lay it on the ground, and its foundations shall be discovered, and it shall fall; and ye shall be consumed with rebukes: and ye shall know that I am the .
I will accomplish my wrath upon the wall, and upon them that plaster it; it shall fall: and I said to you, wall is not, nor they that plaster it,
I will tear your kerchiefs, and will rescue my people out of your hand, and they shall no longer be in your hands to be confounded; and ye shall know that I am the .

14.text: I will set my face against that man, and will make him desolate and ruined, and will cut him off from the midst of my people; and ye shall know that I am the .

15.text: I will set my face against them; they shall go forth of the fire, and yet fire shall devour them; and they shall know that I am the , when I have set my face against them.
I will give up the land to ruin, because they have utterly transgressed, saith the . ublic

16.text: I passed by to thee, and saw thee polluted in thy blood; and I said to thee, there be life out of thy blood:

I passed by thee and saw thee, and, behold, it was thy time and a time of resting; and I spread my wings over thee, and covered thy shame, and sware to thee: and I entered into covenant with thee, saith the , and thou becamest mine.
I washed thee in water, and washed thy blood from thee, and anointed thee with oil.
I clothed thee with embroidered garments , and clothed thee beneath with purple, and girded thee with fine linen, and clothed thee with silk,
I put a pendant on thy nostril, and rings in thine ears, and a crown of glory on thine head.
I will be avenged on thee with the vengeance of an adulteress, and I will bring upon thee blood of fury and jealousy.

I will deliver thee into their hands, and they shall break down thy house of harlotry, and destroy thine high place; and they shall strip thee of thy garments, and shall take thy proud ornaments, and leave thee naked and bare.
I live, saith the , this and her daughters have not done as thou and thy daughters have done.
I will turn their captivity, even the captivity of and her daughters; and I will turn the captivity of and her daughters; and I will turn thy captivity in the midst of them:
I will remember my covenant made with thee in the days of thine infancy, and I will establish to thee an everlasting covenant.
I will establish my covenant with thee; and thou shalt know that I am the :

17.text: I live, saith the , verily in the same place where the king is that made him king, who dishonoured my oath, and who broke my covenant, shall he die with him in the midst of .
I will spread a net upon him, and he shall be caught in its snare.

18.text: I live, saith the , surely this parable shall no more be spoken in .
I at all desire the death of the sinner, saith the , as I desire that he should turn from his evil way, and live?
I will judge you, O house of , saith the , each one according to his way: be converted, and turn from all your ungodliness, and it shall not become to you the punishment of iniquity.
I desire not the death of him that dies, saith the . ublic

20.text: I utterly take vengeance on them, son of man? testify to them of the iniquities of their fathers:
I said to them, every one cast away the abominations of his eyes, and defile not yourselves with the devices of : I am the your .
I wrought so that my name should not be at all profaned in the sight of the , in the midst of whom they are, among whom I was made known to them in their sight, to bring them out of the land of .
I brought them into the wilderness.
I gave them my commandments, and made known to them mine ordinances, all which if a man shall do, he shall even live in them.
I gave them my sabbaths, that they should be for a sign between me and them, that they should know that I am the that sanctify them.

I said to the house of in the wilderness, ye in my commandments: but they walked not in them , and they rejected mine ordinances, which if a man shall do, he shall even live in them; and they grievously profaned my sabbaths: and I said that I would pour out my wrath upon them in the wilderness, to consume them.
I wrought so that my name should not be at all profaned before the , before whose eyes I brought them out.
I lifted up my hand against them in the wilderness once for all, that I would not bring them into the land which I gave them, a land flowing with milk and honey, it is sweeter than all lands:
I said to their children in the wilderness, not ye in the customs of your fathers, and keep not their ordinances, and have no fellowship with their practices, nor defile yourselves with them .
I am the your ; walk in my commandments, and keep mine ordinances, and do them;
I wrought so that my name might not be at all profaned before the ; and I brought them out in their sight.
I lifted up my hand against them in the wilderness, that I would scatter them among the , and disperse them in the countries;
I gave them commandments that were not good, and ordinances in which they should not live.
I will defile them by their own decrees, when I pass through upon every one that opens the womb, that I may destroy them.

I brought them into the land concerning which I lifted up mine hand to give it them; and they looked upon every high hill, and every shady tree, and they sacrificed there to their gods, and offered there a sweet-smelling savour, and there they poured out their drink-offerings.
I said to them, is , that ye go in thither? and they called its name , until this day.
I will bring you out from the nations, and will take you out of the lands wherein ye were dispersed, with a strong hand, and with a high arm, and with outpoured wrath.
I will bring you into the wilderness of the nations, and will plead with you there face to face.
I pleaded with your fathers in the wilderness of the land of , so will I judge you, saith the .
I will cause you to pass under my rod, and I will bring you in by number.

I will separate from among you the ungodly and the revolters; for I will lead them forth out of their place of sojourning, and they shall not enter into the land of : and ye shall know that I am the , even the .

I will accept you with a sweet-smelling savour, when I bring you out from the nations, and take you out of the countries wherein ye have been dispersed; and I will be sanctified among you in the sight of the nations.

21.text: I said, so, O ! they say to me, not this that is spoken a parable?
I will destroy out of thee the unrighteous and the transgressor, therefore so shall my sword come forth out of its sheath against all flesh from the south to the north:
I also will clap my hands, and let loose my fury: I the have spoken it .
I will pour out my wrath upon thee, I will blow upon thee with the fire of my wrath, and I will deliver thee into the hands of barbarians skilled in working destruction.

22.text: I will scatter thee among the nations, and disperse thee in the countries, and thy uncleanness shall be removed out of thee.
I will give heritages in thee in the sight of the nations, and ye shall know that I am the .
I will blow upon you in the fire of my wrath, and ye shall be melted in the midst thereof.
I sought from among them a man behaving uprightly, and standing before me perfectly in the time of wrath, so that I should not utterly destroy her: but I found him not.
I have poured out my wrath upon her in the fury of mine anger, to accomplish it . I have recompensed their ways on their own heads, saith the . ublic

23.text: I delivered her into the hands of her lovers, into the hands of the children of the , on whom she doted.
I saw that they were defiled, that the two had one way.

I will bring upon thee my jealousy, and they shall deal with thee in great wrath: they shall take away thy nose and thine ears; and shall cast down thy remnant with the sword: they shall take thy sons and thy daughters; and thy remnant fire shall devour.
I will turn back thine ungodliness from thee, and thy fornication from the land of : and thou shalt not lift up thine eyes upon them, and shalt no more remember .
I said, they not commit adultery with these? and has she also gone a-whoring after the manner of a harlot?
I will remove ungodliness out of the land, and all the women shall be instructed, and shall not do according to their ungodliness.

24.text: I the have spoken; and it shall come, and I will do it ; I will not delay, neither will I have any mercy: I will judge thee, saith the , according to thy ways, and according to thy devices: therefore will I judge thee according to thy bloodshed, and according to thy devices will I judge thee, thou unclean, notorious, and abundantly provoking one.
I spoke to the people in the morning, as he commanded me in the evening, and I did in the morning as it was commanded me.
I said to them, word of the came to me, saying,

25.text: I will give up the city of for camels' pastures, and the children of for a pasture of sheep: and ye shall know that I am the .
I have given him the children of in addition to the children of for an inheritance, that there may be no remembrance of the children of .
I will execute vengeance on ; and they shall know that I am the .
I will execute my vengeance on by the hand of my people : and they shall deal in according to mine anger and according to my wrath, and they shall know my vengeance, saith the .
I will execute great vengeance upon them; and they shall know that I am the , when I have brought my vengeance upon them. ublic

26.text: I will make thee a bare rock: thou shalt be a place to spread nets upon; thou shalt be built no more: for I the have spoken it , saith the .
I will make thee a destruction, and thou shalt be no more for ever, saith the . ublic

29.text: I will put hooks in thy jaws, and I will cause the fish of thy river to stick to thy sides, and I will bring thee up out of the midst of thy river:

I will cause her land to be utterly destroyed in the midst of a land that is desolate, and her cities shall be desolate forty years in the midst of cities that are desolate: and I will disperse among the nations, and will utterly scatter them into the countries.

30.text: I will make their rivers desolate, and will destroy the land and the fulness of it by the hands of strangers: I the have spoken.
I will destroy the land of , and will send fire upon , and will execute vengeance on .
I will pour out my wrath upon the strength of , and will destroy the multitude of .
I will send fire upon ; and shall be sorely troubled; and there shall be a breaking in , and waters shall be poured out.
I will execute judgment on ; and they shall know that I am the .
