I will strengthen the arms of the king of , and put my sword into his hand: and he shall bring it upon , and shall take her plunder and seize her spoils.
I will disperse the among the nations, and utterly scatter them among the countries; and they all shall know that I am the . ublic

32.text: I will cast thy flesh upon the mountains, and will saturate them with thy blood.
I will veil the heavens when thou art extinguished, and will darken the stars thereof; I will cover the sun with a cloud, and the moon shall not give her light.
I will provoke to anger the heart of many people, when I shall lead thee captive among the nations, to a land which thou hast not known.
I will destroy all her cattle from beside the great water; and the foot of man shall not trouble it any more, and the step of cattle shall no more trample it.

I have caused his fear to be upon the land of the living: yet he shall lie in the midst of the uncircumcised with them that are slain with the sword, even , and all his multitude with him, saith the . ublic

33.text: I say to the sinner, shalt surely die; if thou speak not to warn the wicked from his way, the wicked himself shall die in his iniquity; but his blood will I require at thine hand.

I say to the righteous, shalt live; and he trusts in his righteousness, and shall commit iniquity, none of his righteousnesses shall be remembered; in his unrighteousness which he has wrought, in it shall he die.

I live, surely they that are in the desolate places shall fall by swords, and they that are in the open plain shall be given for food to the wild beasts of the field, and them that are in the fortified cities and them that are in the caves I will slay with pestilence.
I will make the land desert, and the pride of her strength shall perish; and the mountains of shall be made desolate by reason of no man passing through.

34.text: I live, saith the , surely because my sheep became a prey, and my sheep became meat to all the wild beasts of the field, because there were no shepherds, and the shepherds sought not out my sheep, and the shepherds fed themselves, but fed not my sheep.

I will bring them out from the , and will gather them from the countries, and will bring them into their own land, and will feed them upon the mountains of , and in the valleys, and in every inhabited place of the land.

I will feed them in a good pasture, on a high mountain of : and their folds shall be there, and they shall lie down, and there shall they rest in perfect prosperity, and they shall feed in a fat pasture on the mountains of .
I will feed my sheep, and I will cause them to rest; and they shall know that I am the : thus saith the .

I will seek that which is lost, and I will recover the stray one, and will bind up that which was broken, and will strengthen the fainting, and will guard the strong, and will feed them with judgment.
I will save my sheep, and they shall not be any more for a prey; and will judge between ram and ram.
I will raise up one shepherd over them, and he shall tend them, even my servant , and he shall be their shepherd;
I will make with a covenant of peace, and I will utterly destroy evil beasts from off the land; and they shall dwell in the wilderness, and sleep in the forests.
I will settle them round about my mountain; and I will give you the rain, the rain of blessing.
I will raise up for them a plant of peace, and they shall no more perish with hunger upon the land, and they shall no more bear the reproach of the nations.

35.text: I will cause desolation in thy cities, and thou shalt be desolate, and thou shalt know that I am the .
I will make mount a waste, and desolate, and I will destroy from off it men and cattle:
I will make thee a perpetual desolation, and thy cities shall not be inhabited any more: and thou shalt know that I am the .

36.text: I will multiply men and cattle upon you; and I will cause you to dwell as at the beginning, and will treat you well, as in your former times : and ye shall know that I am the .
I will increase men upon you, even my people ; and they shall inherit you, and ye shall be to them for a possession; and ye shall no more be bereaved of them.
I poured out my wrath upon them:
I spared them for the sake of my holy name, which the house of profaned among the nations, among whom they went.

I will sanctify my great name, which was profaned among the nations, which ye profaned in the midst of them; and the nations shall know that I am the , when I am sanctified among you before their eyes.
I will take you out from the nations, and will gather you out of all the lands, and will bring you into your own land:
I will give you a new heart, and will put a new spirit in you: and I will take away the heart of stone out of your flesh, and will give you a heart of flesh.
I will put my in you, and will cause you to walk in mine ordinances, and to keep my judgments, and do them .
I will save you from all your uncleannesses: and I will call for the corn, and multiply it, and will not bring famine upon you.
I will multiply the fruit of the trees, and the produce of the field, that ye may not bear the reproach of famine among the nations.

37.text: I prophesied as the commanded me: and it came to pass while I was prophesying, that, behold, there was a shaking, and the bones approached each one to his joint.
I looked, and, behold, sinews and flesh grew upon them, and skin came upon them above: but there was no breath in them.
I prophesied as he commanded me, and the breath entered into them, and they lived, and stood upon their feet, a very great congregation.
I will put my within you, and ye shall live, and I will place you upon your own land: and ye shall know that I am the ; I have spoken, and will do it , saith the .

I will make them a nation in my land, even on the mountains of ; and they shall have one prince: and they shall be no more two nations, neither shall they be divided any more at all into two kingdoms:
I will make with them a covenant of peace; it shall be an everlasting covenant with them; and I will establish my sanctuary in the midst of them for ever.

38.text: I will summon against it even every fear, saith the : the sword of every man shall be against his brother.
I will judge him with pestilence, and blood, and sweeping rain, and hailstones; and I will rain upon him fire and brimstone, and upon all that are with him, and upon many nations with him.
I will be magnified, and sanctified, and glorified; and I will be known in the presence of many nations, and they shall know that I am the . ublic

39.text: I will destroy thy bow out of thy left hand, and thine arrows out of thy right hand, and I will cast thee down on the mountains of ;
I will send a fire upon , and the islands shall be securely inhabited: and they shall know that I am the .
I will set my glory among you, and all the nations shall see my judgment which I have wrought, and my hand which I have brought upon them.
I will no more turn away my face from them, because I have poured out my wrath upon the house of , saith the . ublic

43.text: I stood, and behold there was a voice out of the house of one speaking to me, and a man stood near me,

2.text: I give thanks to thee, and praise thee , O of my fathers, for thou has given me wisdom and power, and has made known to me the things which we asked of thee; and thou has made known to me the king's vision.
O king: thy thoughts upon thy bed arose as to what must come to pass hereafter: and he that reveals mysteries has made known to thee what must come to pass.

3.text: O king, live for ever.

I publish a decree: people, tribe, or language, that shall speak reproachfully against the of , , and shall be destroyed, and their houses shall be plundered: because there is no other who shall be able to deliver thus.

4.text: I was thriving in my house, and prospering.
I saw a vision, and it terrified me, and I was troubled on my bed, and the visions of my head troubled me.
I made a decree to bring in before me all the wise men of , that they might make known to me the interpretation of the dream.
O , chief of the enchanters, of whom I know that the of is in thee, and no mystery is too hard for thee, hear the vision of my dream which I had, and tell me the interpretation of it.
I had a vision upon my bed; and behold a tree in the midst of the earth, and its height was great.
I beheld in the night vision upon my bed, and, behold, a watcher and an holy one came down from heaven and cried aloud, and thus he said,

5.text: I have heard concerning thee, that the of is in thee, and that watchfulness and understanding and excellent wisdom have been found in thee.

I have heard concerning thee, that thou art able to make interpretations: now then if thou shalt be able to read the writing, and to make known to me the interpretation of it, thou shalt be clothed with purple, and there shall be a golden chain upon thy neck, and thou shalt be third ruler in my kingdom.
O king, the most high gave to thy father a kingdom, and majesty, and honour, and glory:

7.text: I beheld, and, lo, the four winds of heaven blew violently upon the great sea.

I noticed his horns, and behold, another little horn came up in the midst of them, and before it three of the former horns were rooted out: and, behold, there were eyes as the eyes of a man in this horn, and a mouth speaking great things.
I beheld until the thrones were set, and the of days sat; and his raiment was white as snow, and the hair of his head, as pure wool: his throne was a flame of fire, and his wheels burning fire.
A stream of fire rushed forth before him: thousand thousands ministered to him, and ten thousands of myriads, attended upon him: the judgment sat, and the books were opened.
I beheld then because of the voice of the great words which that horn spoke, until the wild beast was slain and destroyed, and his body given to be burnt with fire.
I beheld in the night vision, and, lo, one coming with the clouds of heaven as the of man, and he came on to the of days, and was brought near to him.
I drew near to one of them that stood by, and I sought to learn of him the truth of all these things: and he told me the truth, and made known to me the interpretation of the things.

I enquired carefully concerning the fourth beast; for it differed from every other beast, exceeding dreadful: its teeth were of iron, and its claws of brass, devouring, and utterly breaking to pieces, and it trampled the remainder with its feet:
I beheld, and that horn made war with the saints, and prevailed against them;

8.text: I was in the palace, which is in the land of , and I was on the bank of .
I lifted up mine eyes, and saw, and, behold, a ram standing in front of the ; and he had high horns; and one was higher than the other, and the high one came up last.

I saw the ram butting westward, and northward, and southward; and no beast could stand before him, and there was none that could deliver out of his hand; and he did according to his will, and became great.
I was considering, and, behold, a he-goat came from the south-west on the face of the whole earth, and touched not the earth: and the goat had a horn between his eyes.

I saw him coming up close to the ram, and he was furiously enraged against him, and he smote the ram, and broke both his horns: and there was no strength in the ram to stand before him, but he cast him on the ground, and trampled on him; and there was none that could deliver the ram out of his hand.

I heard one saint speaking, and a saint said to a certain one speaking, long shall the vision continue, even the removal of the sacrifice, and the bringing in of the sin of desolation; and how long shall the sanctuary and host be trampled?
I heard the voice of a man between the banks of the ; and he called, and said, , cause that man to understand the vision.
I fell asleep, and was sick: then I arose, and did the king's business; and I wondered at the vision, and there was none that understood it . ublic

9.text: I understood by books the number of the years which was the word of the to the prophet , even seventy years for the accomplishment of the desolation of .
I set my face toward the , to seek him diligently by prayer and supplications, with fastings and sackcloth.
I prayed to the my , and confessed, and said, O , the great and wonderful , keeping thy covenant and thy mercy to them that love thee, and to them that keep thy commandments; we have sinned,

O , thy mercy is over all: let, I pray thee, thy wrath turn away, and thine anger from thy city , even thy holy mountain: for we have sinned, and because of our iniquities, and those of our fathers, and thy people are become a reproach among all that are round about us.

10.text: I ate no pleasant bread, and no flesh or wine entered into my mouth, neither did I anoint myself with oil, until three whole weeks were accomplished.
I lifted up mine eyes, and looked, and behold a man clothed in linen, and his loins were girt with gold of :
I only saw the vision: and the men that were with me saw not the vision; but a great amazement fell upon them, and they fled in fear.
I was left alone, and saw this great vision, and there was no strength left in me, and my glory was turned into corruption, and I retained no strength.
I heard the voice of his words: and when I heard him I was pricked in the heart , and I fell with my face to the earth.
I will tell thee that which is ordained in the scripture of truth: and there is no one that holds with me in these matters but your prince. ublic

11.text: I in the first year of stood to strengthen and confirm him .

12.text: I saw, and, behold, two others stood, on one side of the bank of the river, and the other on the other side of the bank of the river.

I heard the man clothed in linen, who was over the water of the river, and he lifted up his right hand and his left hand to heaven, and sware by him that lives for ever, that it should be for a time of times and half a time: when the dispersion is ended they shall know all these things.
I heard, but I understood not: and I said, O , what will be the end of these things?

1.text: I will have mercy on the house of , and will save them by the their , and will not save them with bow, nor with sword, nor by war, nor by horses, nor by horsemen.

2.text: I will not have mercy upon her children; for they are children of fornication.
I will return, and take away my corn in its season, and my wine in its time; and I will take away my raiment and my linen clothes, so that she shall not cover her nakedness.
I will take away all her gladness, her feasts, and her festivals at the new moon, and her sabbaths, and all her solemn assemblies.

I will utterly destroy her vines, and her fig-trees, all things of which she said, are my hire which my lovers have given me: and I will make them a testimony, and the wild beasts of the field, and the birds of the sky, and the reptiles of the earth shall devour them.
I will recompense on her the days of , wherein she sacrificed to them, and put on her ear-rings, and her necklaces, and went after her lovers, and forgot me, saith the .

I will give her her possessions from thence, and the valley of to open her understanding: and she shall be afflicted there according to the days of her infancy, and according to the days of her coming up out of the land of .
I will take away the names of out of her mouth, and their names shall be remembered no more at all.

I will make for them in that day a covenant with the wild beasts of the field, and with the birds of the sky, and with the reptiles of the earth: and I will break the bow and the sword and the battle from off the earth, and will cause thee to dwell safely.
I will betroth thee to myself for ever; yea, I will betroth thee to myself in righteousness, and in judgment, and in mercy, and in tender compassions;
I will sow her to me on the earth; and will love her that was not loved, and will say to that which was not my people, art my people; and they shall say, art the my . ublic

3.text: I hired her to myself for fifteen pieces of silver, and a homer of barley, and a flagon of wine.
I said unto her, shalt wait for me many days; and thou shalt not commit fornication, neither shalt thou be for another man; and I will be for thee.

4.text: I will not visit upon your daughters when they shall commit fornication, nor your daughters-in-law when they shall commit adultery: for they themselves mingled themselves with harlots, and sacrificed with polluted ones, and the people that understood not entangled itself with a harlot.

5.text: I know , and is not far from me: for now has gone grievously a-whoring, is defiled.
I will be as consternation to , and as a goad to the house of .
I am as a panther to , and as a lion to the house of : and I will tear, and go away; and I will take, and there shall be none to deliver.
I will go and return to my place, until they are brought to nought, and then shall they seek my face. their affliction they will seek me early, saying, ublic

6.text: I will have mercy rather than sacrifice, and the knowledge of rather than whole-burnt-offerings.
I have seen horrible things there, even the fornication of : and are defiled;

7.text: I have healed , then shall the iniquity of be revealed, and the wickedness of ; for they have wrought falsehood: and a thief shall come in to him, even a robber spoiling in his way;

8.text: I will write down a multitude of commands for him; but his statutes are accounted strange things, even the beloved altars.

9.text: I found as grapes in the wilderness, and I saw their fathers as an early watchman in a fig-tree: they went in to -phegor, and were shamefully estranged, and the abominable became as the beloved.

11.text: I called them, so they departed from my presence: they sacrificed to , and burnt incense to graven images.
I bound the feet of , I took him on my arm; but they knew not that I healed them.
I will not act according to the fury of my wrath, I will not abandon to be utterly destroyed: for I am , and not man; the within thee: and I will not enter into the city.
I will go after the : he shall utter his voice as a lion: for he shall roar, and the children of the waters shall be amazed.

12.text: I the thy brought thee up out of the land of : I will yet cause thee to dwell in tabernacles, according to the days of the feast.
I will speak to the prophets, and I have multiplied visions, and by the means of the prophets I was represented.

13.text: I am the thy that establishes the heaven, and creates the earth, whose hands have framed the whole host of heaven: but I shewed them not to thee that thou shouldest go after them: and I brought thee up out of the land of , and thou shalt know no but me; and there is no beside me.
I tended thee as a shepherd in the wilderness, in an uninhabited land.
I will be to them as a panther, and as a leopard.

I will meet them by the way of the , as a she-bear excited, and I will rend the caul of their heart, and the lions' whelps of the thicket shall devour them there; the wild beasts of the field shall rend them in pieces.
O , who will aid thee in thy destruction?
I gave thee a king in mine anger, and kept him back in my wrath.
I will deliver them out of the power of , and will redeem them from death: where is thy penalty, O death? O , where is thy sting? comfort is hidden from mine eyes.

14.text: I will restore their dwellings, I will love them truly: for he has turned away my wrath from him.
I will be as dew to : he shall bloom as the lily, and cast forth his roots as .

2.text: I will recompense you for the years which the locust, and the caterpillar, and the palmerworm, and the cankerworm have eaten, even my great army, which I sent against you.

3.text: I will shew wonders in heaven, and upon the earth, blood, and fire, and vapour of smoke.

4.text: I will sell your sons and your daughters into the hands of the children of , and they shall sell them into captivity to a far distant nation: for the has spoken it .
I will make inquisition for their blood, and will by no means leave it unavenged: and the shall dwell in . <

1.text: I will send a fire on the house of , and it shall devour the foundations of the son of .

I will break to pieces the bars of , and will destroy the inhabitants out of the plain of , and will cut in pieces a tribe out of the men of : and the famous people of shall be led captive, saith the .
I will send forth a fire on the walls of , and it shall devour its foundations.
I will destroy the inhabitants out of , and a tribe shall be cut off from , and I will stretch out my hand upon : and the remnant of the shall perish, saith the .
I will send forth a fire on the walls of , and it shall devour the foundations of it.
I will send forth a fire upon , and it shall devour the foundations of her walls.
I will kindle a fire on the walls of , and it shall devour her foundations with shouting in the day of war, and she shall be shaken in the days of her destruction:

2.text: I will send forth a fire on , and it shall devour the foundations of its cities: and shall perish in weakness, with a shout, and with the sound of a trumpet.
I will destroy the judge out of her, and slay all her princes with him, saith the .
I will send a fire on , and it shall devour the foundations of .
I cut off the from before them, whose height was as the height of a cedar, and he was strong as an oak; and I dried up his fruit from above, and his roots from beneath.
I brought you up out of the land of , and led you about in the desert forty years, that ye should inherit the land of the .
I took of your sons for prophets, and of your young men for consecration. not these things so, ye sons of ? saith the .

3.text: A lion shall roar, and who will not be alarmed? the has spoken, and who will not prophesy?
I will crush and smite the turreted-house upon the summer-house; and the ivory-houses shall be destroyed, and many other houses also, saith the . ublic

4.text: I will give you dulness of teeth in all your cities, and want of bread in all your places: yet ye returned not to me, saith the .

I withheld from you the rain three months before the harvest: and I will rain upon one city, and on another city I will not rain: one part shall be rained upon, and the part on which I shall not rain shall be dried up.

I smote you with parching, and with blight: ye multiplied your gardens, your vineyards, and your fig-grounds, and the cankerworm devoured your oliveyards: yet not even thus did ye return to me, saith the .

I sent pestilence among you by the way of , and slew your young men with the sword, together with thy horses that were taken captive; and in my wrath against you I set fire to your camps: yet not even thus did ye return to me, saith the .
I overthrew you, as overthrew and , and ye became as a brand plucked out of the fire: yet not even thus did ye return to me, saith the .

5.text: I know your many transgressions, and your sins are great, trampling on the just, taking bribes, and turning aside the judgment of the poor in the gates.
I hate, I reject your feasts, and I will not smell your meat-offerings in your general assemblies.
I will carry you away beyond , saith the , the is his name. ublic

6.text: O house of , pass by all of you , and see; and pass by thence to ; and thence descend to of the , the chief of all these kingdoms, see if their coasts are greater than your coasts.

7.text: I said, O , cease, I pray thee: who shall raise up ? for he is small in number. , O , for this.

9.text: I saw the standing on the altar: and he said, the mercy-seat, and the porch shall be shaken: and cut through into the heads of all; and I will slay the remnant of them with the sword: no one of them fleeing shall escape, and no one of them striving to save himself shall be delivered.
I will give commandment, and sift the house of among all the , as corn is sifted in a sieve, and yet a fragment shall not in any wise fall upon the earth.

I will turn the captivity of my people , and they shall rebuild the ruined cities, and shall inhabit them ; and they shall plant vineyards, and shall drink the wine from them; and they shall form gardens, and eat the fruit of them.
I will plant them on their land, and they shall no more be plucked up from the land which I have given them, saith the . ublic

2.text: I said, I am cast out of thy presence: shall I indeed look again toward thy holy temple?
I will sacrifice to thee with the voice of praise and thanksgiving: all that I have vowed I will pay to thee, § , for a thank-offering to the . the of my salvation.

1.text: I will make as a store-house of the fruits of the field, and as a planting of a vineyard: and I will utterly demolish her stones, and I will expose her foundations.

3.text: I will strengthen myself with the of the , and of judgment, and of power, to declare to his transgressions, and to his sins.

4.text: I will make her that was bruised a remnant, and her that was rejected a mighty nation: and the shall reign over them in mount from henceforth, even for ever.

5.text: I will utterly destroy thy graven images, and thy statues out of the midst of thee; and thou shalt never any more worship the works of thine hands.
I will cut off the groves out of the midst of thee, and I will abolish thy cities.
I will execute vengeance on the heathen in anger and wrath, because they hearkened not. Ã¦as <

6.text: O my people, what have I done to thee? or wherein have I grieved thee? or wherein have I troubled thee? answer me.
I brought thee up out of the land of , and redeemed thee out of the house of bondage, and sent before thee , and , and .
O my people, remember now, what counsel king of took against thee, and what the son of answered him, from the reeds to ; that the righteousness of the might be known.

7.text: I will look to the ; I will wait upon my : my will hearken to me.

I will bear the indignation of the , because I have sinned against him, until he make good my cause: he also shall maintain my right, and shall bring me out to the light, and I shall behold his righteousness.

3.text: O city of blood, wholly false, full of unrighteousness; the prey shall not be handled.
I will cast abominable filth upon thee according to thine unclean ways, and will make thee a public example.

2.text: I will stand upon my watch, and mount upon the rock, and watch to see what he will say by me, and what I shall answer when I am reproved.

3.text: A of the , with a .

O , I have heard thy report, and was afraid: I considered thy works, and was amazed: thou shalt be known between the two living creatures, thou shalt be acknowledged when the years draw nigh; thou shalt be manifested when the time is come; when my soul is troubled, thou wilt in wrath remember mercy.

I watched, and my belly trembled at the sound of the prayer of my lips, and trembling entered into my bones, and my frame was troubled within me; I will rest in the day of affliction, from going up to the people of my sojourning.

1.text: I will stretch out mine hand upon , and upon all the inhabitants of ; and I will remove the names of out of this place, and the names of the priests;
I will openly take vengeance on the porches in that day, on the men that fill the house of the their with ungodliness and deceit.
A mighty day of wrath is that day, a day of affliction and distress, a day of desolation and destruction, a day of gloominess and darkness, a day of cloud and vapour,
I will greatly afflict the men, and they shall walk as blind men, because they have sinned against the ; therefore he shall pour out their blood as dust, and their flesh as dung.

2.text: I have heard the revilings of , and the insults of the children of , wherewith they have reviled my people, and magnified themselves against my coasts.

3.text: I have brought down the proud with destruction; their corners are destroyed: I will make their ways completely waste, so that none shall go through: their cities are come to an end, by reason of no man living or dwelling in them .

I said, do ye fear me, and receive instruction, and ye shall not be cut off from the face of the land for all the vengeance I have brought upon her: prepare thou, rise early: all their produce is spoilt.
I will leave in thee a meek and lowly people;
I will gather thine afflicted ones. ! who has taken up a reproach against her?

1.text: I will bring a sword upon the land, and upon the mountains, and upon the corn, and upon the wine, and upon the oil, and all that the earth produces, and upon the men, and upon the cattle, and upon all the labours of their hands.

2.text: I smote you with barrenness, and with blasting, and all the works of your hands with hail; yet ye returned not to me, saith the .

1.text: I saw by night, and behold a man mounted on a red horse, and he stood between the shady mountains; and behind him were red horses, and grey, and piebald, and white.
I said, are these, my lord? the angel that spoke with me said to me, I will shew thee what these things are.
I am very angry with the heathen that combine to attack her : forasmuch as I indeed was a little angry, but they combined to attack her for evil.

2.text: I lifted up mine eyes and looked, and behold four horns.
I said to the angel that spoke with me, are these things, my lord? he said to me, are the horns that have scattered , and , and .

I said, are these coming to do? he said, are the horns that scattered , and they broke in pieces, and none of them lifted up his head: and these are come forth to sharpen them for their hands, even the four horns, the nations that lifted up the horn against the land of the to scatter it.
I lifted up mine eyes, and looked, and behold a man, and in his hand a measuring line.
I said to him, goest thou? he said to me, measure , to see what is the breadth of it, and what is the length of it.
I will be to her, saith the , a wall of fire round about, and I will be for a glory in the midst of her.

4.text: I inquired, and spoke to the angel that talked with me, saying, are these things, my lord?
I answered, and said to him, are these two olive-trees, which are on the right and left hand of the candlestick?
I asked the second time, and said to him, are the two branches of the olive-trees that are by the side of the two golden . nostrils. pipes that pour into and communicate with the golden oil funnels?

5.text: I turned, and lifted up mine eyes, and looked and behold a flying sickle.

I will bring it forth, saith the , and it shall enter into the house of the thief, and into the house of him that swears falsely by my name: and it shall rest in the midst of his house, and shall consume it, and the timber of it, and the stones of it.
I said, is it? he said, is the measure that goes forth. he said, is their iniquity in all the earth.
I lifted up mine eyes, and saw, and, behold, two women coming forth, and the wind was in their wings; and they had stork's wings: and they lifted up the measure between the earth and the sky.
I said to the angel that spoke with me, do these carry away the measure?

6.text: I turned, and lifted up mine eyes, and looked, and, behold, four chariots coming out from between two mountains; and the mountains were brazen mountains.
I answered and said to the angel that talked with me, are these, my lord?

7.text: I will cast them out among all the nations, whom they know not; and the land behind them shall be made utterly destitute of any going through or returning: yea they have made the choice land a desolation. ublic

8.text: I will shew peace: the vine shall yield her fruit, and the land shall yield her produce, and the heaven shall give its dew: and I will give as an inheritance all these things to the remnant of my people.

9.text: I will take their blood out of their mouth, and their abominations from between their teeth; and these also shall be left to our , and they shall be as a captain of a thousand in , and as a .
I have bent thee, O , for myself as a bow, I have filled ** , it with . ; and I will raise up thy children, O , against the children of the , and I will handle thee as the sword of a warrior.

10.text: I will strengthen the house of , and save the house of , and I will settle them; because I have loved them: and they shall be as if I had not cast them off: for I am the their , and I will hear them.
I will make a sign to them, and gather them in; for I will redeem them, and they shall be multiplied according to their number before.
I will sow them among the people; and they that are afar off shall remember me: they shall nourish their children, and they shall return.
I will bring them again from the land of , and I will gather them in from among the ; and I will bring them into the land of and to ; and there shall not even one of them be left behind.
I will strengthen them in the their ; and they shall boast in his name, saith the . <

11.text: I will no longer have mercy upon the inhabitants of the land, saith the : but, behold, I will deliver up the men every one into the hand of his neighbour, and into the hand of his king; and they shall destroy the land, and I will not rescue out of their hand.
I will tend the flock of slaughter in the land of : and I will take for myself two rods; the one I called , and the other I called ; and I will tend the flock.
I will cut off three shepherds in one month; and my soul shall , be sorely displeased with them. . be weighed down upon them. grieve over them, for their souls cried out against me.
I said, I will not tend you: that which dies, let it die; and that which § , fails. falls off, let it fall off; and let the rest eat every one the flesh of his neighbour.
I will take my beautiful staff, and cast it away, that I may break my covenant which I made with all the people.
I will say to them, it be good in your eyes, give me my price, or refuse it. they weighed for my price thirty pieces of silver.
I cast away my second rod, even , that I might break the ** . . Î´Î¹Î±Î¸Î®ÎºÎ·Î½ covenant. possession between and .

13.text: I will say to him, are these wounds between thine hands? and he shall say, with which I was wounded in . house of my beloved. my beloved house.

I will bring the third part through the fire, and I will try them as silver is tried, and I will prove them as gold is proved: they shall call upon my name, and I will hear them, and say, is my people: and they shall say, is my . <

14.text: I will gather all the to to war, and the city shall be taken, and the houses plundered, and the women ravished; and half of the city shall go forth into captivity, but the rest of my people shall not be utterly cut off from the city.

1.text: A son honours his father, and a servant his master: if then I am a father, where is mine honour? and if I am a master, where is my fear? saith the . the priests are they that despise my name: yet ye said, have we despised thy name?

2.text: I have made you despised and cast out among all the people, because ye have not kept my ways, but have ** . accepted persons. been partial in the law.

3.text: I will draw near to you in judgment; and I will be a swift witness against the witches, and against the adulteresses, and against them that swear falsely by my name, and against them that keep back the hireling's wages, and them that oppress the widow, and § . beat with the fist. afflict orphans, and that wrest the judgment of the stranger, and fear not me, saith the .
I am the your , and I am not changed:
I will , give a charge for you to be fed. . appoint food for you, and I will not destroy the fruit of your land; and your vine in the field shall not fail, saith the .

1.text: I have walked all the days of my life in the way of truth and justice, and I did many alms-deeds to my brethren, and my nation, who came with me to , into the land of the .

I alone went often to at the feasts, as it was ordained unto all the people of by an everlasting decree, having the first-fruits and tenths of increase, with that which was first shorn; and them gave I at the altar to the priests the children of .
I kept myself from eating;
I went into , and left in trust with , the brother of , at a city of , ten talents of silver.

2.text: I returned, and washed myself, and ate my meat in heaviness,
I wept: and after the going down of the sun I went and made a grave, and buried him.

3.text: I being grieved did weep, and in my sorrow prayed, saying,
O , thou art just, and all thy works and all thy ways are mercy and truth, and thou judgest truly and justly for ever.

7.text: I have given my daughter in marriage to seven men, who died that night they came in unto her: nevertheless for the present be merry. said, I will eat nothing here, till we agree and swear one to another.

10.text: I care for nothing, my son, since I have let thee go, the light of mine eyes.

12.text: I will keep close nothing from you. I said, was good to keep close the secret of a king, but that it was honourable to reveal the works of .
I am , one of the seven holy angels, which present the prayers of the saints, and which go in and out before the glory of the .

13.text: O blessed are they which love thee, for they shall rejoice in thy peace: blessed are they which have been sorrowful for all thy scourges; for they shall rejoice for thee, when they have seen all thy glory, and shall be glad for ever.

2.text: A great number also of sundry countries came with them like locusts, and like the sand of the earth: for the multitude was without number.

6.text: O of heaven, behold their pride, and pity the low estate of our nation, and look upon the face of those that are sanctified unto thee this day.

9.text: O of my father , to whom thou gavest a sword to take vengeance of the strangers, who loosened the girdle of a maid to defile her, and discovered the thigh to her shame, and polluted her virginity to her reproach; for thou saidst, shall not be so; and yet they did so:
I pray thee, I pray thee, O of my father, and of the inheritance of , of the heavens and earth, of the waters, of every creature, hear thou my prayer:

11.text: I thine handmaid, knowing all this, am fled from their presence; and hath sent me to work things with thee, whereat all the earth shall be astonished, and whosoever shall hear it.

I will lead thee through the midst of , until thou come before ; and I will set thy throne in the midst thereof; and thou shalt drive them as sheep that have no shepherd, and a dog shall not so much as open his mouth at thee: for these things were told me according to my foreknowledge, and they were declared unto me, and I am sent to tell thee.

16.text: I will sing unto my a new song: O , thou art great and glorious, wonderful in strength, and invincible.

7.text: I myself also am a mortal man, like to all, and the offspring of him that was first made of the earth,
I was nursed in swaddling clothes, and that with cares.
I prayed, and understanding was given me: I called upon , and the spirit of wisdom came to me.
I preferred her before sceptres and thrones, and esteemed riches nothing in comparison of her.
I loved her above health and beauty, and chose to have her instead of light: for the light that cometh from her never goeth out.
I rejoiced in them all, because wisdom goeth before them: and I knew not that she was the mother of them.
I learned diligently, and do communicate her liberally: I do not hide her riches.

8.text: I loved her, and sought her out from my youth, I desired to make her my spouse, and I was a lover of her beauty.
I purposed to take her to me to live with me, knowing that she would be a counsellor of good things, and a comfort in cares and grief.
I shall be found of a quick conceit in judgment, and shall be admired in the sight of great men.
I hold my tongue, they shall bide my leisure, and when I speak, they shall give good ear unto me: if I talk much, they shall lay their hands upon their mouth.
I shall set the people in order, and the nations shall be subject unto me.
I am come into mine house, I will repose myself with her: for her conversation hath no bitterness: and to live with her hath no sorrow, but mirth and joy.
I was a witty child, and had a good spirit.

9.text: O of my fathers, and of mercy, who hast made all things with thy word,
O send her out of thy holy heavens, and from the throne of thy glory, that being present she may labour with me, that I may know what is pleasing unto thee.

16.text: A man indeed killeth through his malice: and the spirit, when it is gone forth, returneth not; neither the soul received up cometh again.

1.text: A furious man cannot be justified; for the sway of his fury shall be his destruction.
A patient man will bear for a time, and afterward joy shall spring up unto him.

3.text: A stubborn heart shall fare evil at the last; and he that loveth danger shall perish therein.

6.text: A wicked soul shall destroy him that hath it, and shall make him to be laughed to scorn of his enemies.
A faithful friend is a strong defence: and he that hath found such an one hath found a treasure.
A faithful friend is the medicine of life; and they that fear the shall find him.

7.text: A gift hath grace in the sight of every man living; and for the dead detain it not.

9.text: A man of an ill tongue is dangerous in his city; and he that is rash in his talk shall be hated. ublic

10.text: A wise judge will instruct his people; and the government of a prudent man is well ordered.

12.text: A friend cannot be known in prosperity: and an enemy cannot be hidden in adversity.

13.text: A rich man beginning to fall is held up of his friends: but a poor man being down is thrust also away by his friends.
A cheerful countenance is a token of a heart that is in prosperity; and the finding out of parables is a wearisome labour of the mind. ublic

14.text: A covetous man's eye is not satisfied with his portion; and the iniquity of the wicked drieth up his soul.
A wicked eye envieth [his] bread, and he is a niggard at his table.

16.text: I will shew forth doctrine in weight, and declare his knowledge exactly.

18.text: A fool will upbraid churlishly, and a gift of the envious consumeth the eyes.
A wise man will fear in every thing, and in the day of sinning he will beware of offence: but a fool will not observe time.

19.text: A labouring man that is given to drunkenness shall not be rich: and he that contemneth small things shall fall by little and little.
A fool travaileth with a word, as a woman in labour of a child.
A man may be known by his look, and one that hath understanding by his countenance, when thou meetest him.
A man's attire, and excessive laughter, and gait, shew what he is. ublic

20.text: A wise man will hold his tongue till he see opportunity: but a babbler and a fool will regard no time.
A wise man by his words maketh himself beloved: but the graces of fools shall be poured out.
A wise sentence shall be rejected when it cometh out of a fool's mouth; for he will not speak it in due season.
A lie is a foul blot in a man, yet it is continually in the mouth of the untaught.
A thief is better than a man that is accustomed to lie: but they both shall have destruction to heritage.
A wise man shall promote himself to honour with his words: and he that hath understanding will please great men.

21.text: A prayer out of a poor man's mouth reacheth to the ears of , and his judgment cometh speedily.
A fool lifteth up his voice with laughter; but a wise man doth scarce smile a little.
A foolish man's foot is soon in [his neighbour's] house: but a man of experience is ashamed of him.
A fool will peep in at the door into the house: but he that is well nurtured will stand without.
A whisperer defileth his own soul, and is hated wheresoever he dwelleth. ublic

22.text: A slothful man is compared to a filthy stone, and every one will hiss him out to his disgrace.
A slothful man is compared to the filth of a dunghill: every man that takes it up will shake his hand.
A wise daughter shall bring an inheritance to her husband: but she that liveth dishonestly is her father's heaviness.
A tale out of season [is as] music in mourning: but stripes and correction of wisdom are never out of time.
A heart settled upon a thought of understanding is as a fair plaistering on the wall of a gallery.
I will not be ashamed to defend a friend; neither will I hide myself from him;

23.text: O , and of my life, leave me not to their counsels, and let me not fall by them.
O , and of my life, give me not a proud look.

A man that useth much swearing shall be filled with iniquity, and the plague shall never depart from his house: if he shall offend, his sin shall be upon him: and if he acknowledge not his sin, he maketh a double offence: and if he swear in vain, he shall not be innocent, but his house shall be full of calamities.
A man that breaketh wedlock, saying thus in his heart, seeth me? I am compassed about with darkness, the walls cover me, and no body seeth me; what need I to fear? the most will not remember my sins:

24.text: I came out of the mouth of the most , and covered the earth as a cloud.
I dwelt in high places, and my throne is in a cloudy pillar.
I alone compassed the circuit of heaven, and walked in the bottom of the deep.
I took root in an honourable people, even in the portion of the 's inheritance.
I was exalted like a cedar in , and as a cypress tree upon the mountains of .
I was exalted like a palm tree on the sea shore, and as a rose plant in , as a fair olive tree in a plain, and grew up as a plane tree.
I gave a sweet smell like cinnamon and aspalathus, and I yielded a pleasant odour like the best myrrh, as galbanum, and onyx, and sweet storax, and as the fume of frankincense in the tabernacle.
I also came out as a brook from a river, and as a conduit into a garden.
I said, I will water my best garden, and will water abundantly my garden bed: and, lo, my brook became a river, and my river became a sea.
I will yet make doctrine to shine as the morning, and will send forth her light afar off.
I will yet pour out doctrine as prophecy, and leave it to all ages for ever.

25.text: O how comely a thing is judgment for grey hairs, and for ancient men to know counsel!
O how comely is the wisdom of old men, and understanding and counsel to men of honour!
O how great is he that findeth wisdom! yet there is none above him that feareth the .
I had rather dwell with a lion and a dragon, than to keep house with a wicked woman.
A woman, if she maintain her husband, is full of anger, impudence, and much reproach.
A wicked woman abateth the courage, maketh an heavy countenance and a wounded heart: a woman that will not comfort her husband in distress maketh weak hands and feeble knees.

26.text: A virtuous woman rejoiceth her husband, and he shall fulfil the years of his life in peace.
A good wife is a good portion, which shall be given in the portion of them that fear the .
A drunken woman and a gadder abroad causeth great anger, and she will not cover her own shame.
A silent and loving woman is a gift of the ; and there is nothing so much worth as a mind well instructed.
A shamefaced and faithful woman is a double grace, and her continent mind cannot be valued.
A merchant shall hardly keep himself from doing wrong; and an huckster shall not be freed from sin. ublic

27.text: I have hated many things, but nothing like him; for the will hate him.

28.text: A sinful man disquieteth friends, and maketh debate among them that be at peace.
A backbiting tongue hath disquieted many, and driven them from nation to nation: strong cities hath it pulled down, and overthrown the houses of great men.
A backbiting tongue hath cast out virtuous women, and deprived them of their labours.

29.text: A sinner will overthrow the good estate of his surety:
A wicked man transgressing the commandments of the shall fall into suretyship: and he that undertaketh and followeth other men's business for gain shall fall into suits.

30.text: I awaked up last of all, as one that gathereth after the grape-gatherers: by the blessing of the I profited,
A yoke and a collar do bow the neck: so are tortures and torments for an evil servant.

31.text: A man that hath travelled knoweth many things: and he that hath much experience will declare wisdom.
I travelled, I saw many things; and I understand more than I can express.
I was oft-times in danger of death: yet I was delivered because of these things.

33.text: A cheerful and good heart will have a care of his meat and diet. ublic

34.text: A very little is sufficient for a man well nurtured, and he fetcheth not his wind short upon his bed.

35.text: A concert of music in a banquet of wine is as a signet of carbuncle set in gold.
A sinful man will not be reproved, but findeth an excuse according to his will.
A man of counsel will be considerate; but a strange and proud man is not daunted with fear, even when of himself he hath done without counsel.

36.text: A wise man hateth not the law; but he that is an hypocrite therein is as a ship in a storm.
A man of understanding trusteth in the law; and the law is faithful unto him, as an oracle.
A stallion horse is as a mocking friend, he neigheth under every one that sitteth upon him.
I was the last to wake up, yet I received their inheritance as from the beginning.
O have mercy upon the people that is called by thy name, and upon , whom thou hast named thy firstborn.
O be merciful unto , thy holy city, the place of thy rest.
O , hear the prayer of thy servants, according to the blessing of over thy people, that all they which dwell upon the earth may know that thou art the , the eternal .
A froward heart causeth heaviness: but a man of experience will recompense him.
A woman will receive every man, yet is one daughter better than another.

37.text: O wicked imagination, whence camest thou in to cover the earth with deceit?
A wise man instructeth his people; and the fruits of his understanding fail not.
A wise man shall be filled with blessing; and all they that see him shall count him happy.
A wise man shall inherit glory among his people, and his name shall be perpetual.

39.text: A man need not to say, is this? wherefore is that? for he hath made all things for their uses.

40.text: A friend and companion never meet amiss: but above both is a wife with her husband.

41.text: O death, how bitter is the remembrance of thee to a man that liveth at rest in his possessions, unto the man that hath nothing to vex him, and that hath prosperity in all things: yea, unto him that is yet able to receive meat!
O death, acceptable is thy sentence unto the needy, and unto him whose strength faileth, that is now in the last age, and is vexed with all things, and to him that despaireth, and hath lost patience!
A good life hath but few days: but a good name endureth for ever.
A man that hideth his foolishness is better than a man that hideth his wisdom.

42.text: A daughter is a wakeful care to a father; and the care for her taketh away sleep: when she is young, lest she pass away the flower of her age; and being married, lest she should be hated:
I will now remember the works of the , and declare the things that I have seen: the words of the are his works.

43.text: A man blowing a furnace is in works of heat, but the sun burneth the mountains three times more; breathing out fiery vapours, and sending forth bright beams, it dimmeth the eyes.
A present remedy of all is a mist coming speedily: a dew coming after heat refresheth.

48.text: O , how wast thou honoured in thy wondrous deeds! and who may glory like unto thee!

51.text: I will thank thee, O and , and praise thee, O my : I do give praise unto thy name:
I called upon the , the of my , that he would not leave me in the days of my trouble, and in the time of the proud, when there was no help.
I will praise thy name continually, and will sing praise with thanksgiving; and so my prayer was heard:
I was yet young, or ever I went abroad, I desired wisdom openly in my prayer.
I prayed for her before the temple, and will seek her out even to the end.
I bowed down mine ear a little, and received her, and gat much learning.
I profited therein, therefore will I ascribe the glory unto him that giveth me wisdom.
I purposed to do after her, and earnestly I followed that which is good; so shall I not be confounded.
I directed my soul unto her, and I found her in pureness: I have had my heart joined with her from the beginning, therefore shall I not be forsaken.
I opened my mouth, and said, her for yourselves without money.

O , look down from thine holy house, and consider us: bow down thine ear, O , to hear us.

I will cause to cease out of the cities of , and from without , the voice of mirth, and the voice of joy, the voice of the bridegroom, and the voice of the bride: and the whole land shall be desolate of inhabitants.
O our , thou hast dealt with us after all thy goodness, and according to all that great mercy of thine,
I knew that they would not hear me, because it is a stiffnecked people: but in the land of their captivities they shall remember themselves,
I will bring them again into the land which I promised with an oath unto their fathers, , , and , and they shall be lords of it: and I will increase them, and they shall not be diminished.
I will make an everlasting covenant with them to be their , and they shall be my people: and I will no more drive my people of out of the land that I have given them. ublic

I have put off the clothing of peace, and put upon me the sackcloth of my prayer: I will cry unto the in my days.
I sent you out with mourning and weeping: but will give you to me again with joy and gladness for ever.
I will take away the rejoicing of her great multitude, and her pride shall be turned into mourning.
O , look about thee toward the east, and behold the joy that cometh unto thee from .

6.text: I thought with myself, what tribulation am I come, and how great a flood of misery is it wherein now I am! for I was bountiful and beloved in my power.
I perceive therefore that for this cause these troubles are come upon me, and, behold, I perish through great grief in a strange land.

7.text: O , when they that were sent from the king of the blasphemed, thine angel went out and smote an hundred fourscore and five thousand of them.

10.text: I also will write unto them words of encouragement, and promise them dignities and gifts, that I may have their aid.
I freely set at liberty every one of the , that were carried captives out of the land of into any part of my kingdom, and I will that all my officers remit the tributes even of their cattle.

I will that all the feasts, and sabbaths, and new moons, and solemn days, and the three days before the feast, and the three days after the feast, shall be all days of immunity and freedom for all the in my realm.
I will further, that there be enrolled among the king's forces about thirty thousand men of the , unto whom pay shall be given, as belongeth to all the king's forces.
I give every year fifteen thousand shekels of silver out of the king's accounts from the places appertaining.

13.text: I will avenge my nation, and the sanctuary, and our wives, and our children: for all the heathen are gathered to destroy us of very malice.

15.text: I give thee leave also to coin money for thy country with thine own stamp.

6.text: I beseech those that read this book, that they be not discouraged for these calamities, but that they judge those punishments not to be for destruction, but for a chastening of our nation.

7.text: I cannot tell how ye came into my womb; for I neither gave you breath nor life, neither was it I that formed the members of every one of you;
I beseech thee, my son, look upon the heaven and the earth, and all that is therein, and consider that made them of things that were not; and so was mankind made likewise.

I, as my brethren, offer up my body and life for the laws of our fathers, beseeching that he would speedily be merciful unto our nation; and that thou by torments and plagues mayest confess, that he alone is ;

9.text: I pray and request you to remember the benefits that I have done unto you generally, and in special, and that every man will be still faithful to me and my son.
I am persuaded that he understanding my mind will favourably and graciously yield to your desires.

11.text: I have sent also , that he may comfort you.

14.text: I, being deprived of mine ancestors' honour, I mean the high priesthood, am now come hither:

1.text: I am not sent out from the against thee; for my war is upon : and now the is with me, yea the is with me hasting me forward: depart from me, and be not against the .

2.text: I have read the epistle which ye have sent unto me: therefore I commanded to make diligent search, and it hath been found that that city was from the beginning practising against kings;

3.text: O ye men, is not wine the strongest, that enforceth to do thus? when he had so spoken, he held his peace. I <

4.text: O ye men, do not men excel in strength, that bear rule over sea and land, and all things in them?
O ye men, how should not the king be mightiest, when in such sort he is obeyed? he held his tongue.
O ye men, it is not the great king, nor the multitude of men, neither is it wine, that excelleth: who is it then that ruleth them, or hath the lordship over them? are they not women?
A man leaveth his own father that brought him up, and his own country, and cleaveth unto his wife.
O ye men, how can it be but women should be strong, seeing they do thus?

O ye men, are not women strong? great is the earth, high is the heaven, swift is the sun in his course, for he compasseth the heavens round about, and fetcheth his course again to his own place in one day.

6.text: I have commanded also to have it built up whole again; and that they look diligently to help those that be of the captivity of the , till the house of the be finished:
I the king have ordained that according unto these things it be done with diligence. I <

8.text: I king have also commanded the keepers of the treasures in and , that whatsoever the priest and the reader of the law of the most high shall send for, they should give it him with speed,

I command you also, that ye require no tax, nor any other imposition, of any of the priests, or , or holy singers, or porters, or ministers of the temple, or of any that have doings in this temple, and that no man have authority to impose any thing upon them.
I bade them that they should go unto the captain, who was in the place of the treasury:
I separated twelve of the chief of the priests, , and , and ten men of their brethren with them:
I said unto them, ye are holy unto the , and the vessels are holy, and the gold and the silver is a vow unto the , the of our fathers.
I said, O , I am confounded and ashamed before thy face;
O of , thou art true: for we are left a root this day.

1.text: O , the of our fathers and and and of their righteous seed;
I have sinned, , I have sinned, and I acknowledge my transgressions:

A fierce battle then took place; and the men of prevailing, continually went up and down the ranks, and with dishevelled hair, with tears and entreaties, begged the soldiers to fight manfully for themselves, their children, and wives; and promised that if they proved conquerors, she would give them two minÃ¦ of gold apiece.

2.text: O , , of the heavens, and of the whole creation, among the holy, sole , , give ear to us who are oppressed by a wicked and profane one, who exulteth in his confidence and strength.
A nobler spirit, however, prompted the majority to cling to their religious observances, and by paying money that they might live unmolested, these sought to escape the registration:

3.text: I am right well; and so, too, are my affairs.

4.text: A multitude of aged hoary-haired men, were driven along with halting bending feet, urged onward by the impulse of a violent, shameless force to quick speed.

5.text: O king, how long dost thou make trial of us, as of men bereft of reason? is the third time that thou hast ordered their destruction. the thing is to be done, thou changest thy mind, and recallest thy instructions.

6.text: O , mighty in power, most high, , who regulatest the whole creation with thy tender mercy,

1.text: I am going to demonstrate a most philosophical proposition, namely, that religious reasoning is absolute master of the passions, I would willingly advise you to give the utmost heed to philosophy.
I might prove to you, from many other considerations, that religious reasoning is sole master of the passions;

2.text: A man, therefore, who regulates his course by the law, even if he be a lover of money, straightway puts force upon his own disposition; lending to the needy without interest, and cancelling the debt of the incoming sabbath.

5.text: I would counsel thee, old man, before thy tortures begin, to taste the swine's flesh, and save your life; for I feel respect for your age and hoary head, which since you have had so long, you appear to me to be no philosopher in retaining the superstition of the .
I am not so old, and void of manliness, but that my rational powers are youthful in defence of my religion.
I will not so compassionate my old age, as on my account to break the law of my country.
I will not belie thee, O law, my instructor! or forsake thee, O beloved self-control.
I will not put thee to shame, O philosopher ; or deny thee, O honoured priesthood, and science of the law.

7.text: O priest, worthy of the priesthood! thou didst not pollute thy sacred teeth; nor make thy appetite, which had always embraced the clean and lawful, a partaker of profanity.
O harmonizer with the law, and sage devoted to a divine life!
O aged man of more power than tortures, elder more vigorous than fire, greatest king over the passions, !
O blessed old age, and reverend hoar head, and life obedient to the law, which the faithful seal of death perfected.

8.text: O youths, with favourable feelings, I admire the beauty of each of you; and greatly honouring so numerous a band of brethren, I not only counsel you not to share the madness of the old man who has been tortured before,
O wretched that we are, and exceeding senseless! when the king exhorts us, and calls us to his bounty, should we not obey him?

9.text: O tyrant, counsellor of law-breaking, do not, hating us as thou dost, pity us more than we pity ourselves.
O most accursed tyrant, and enemy of heavenly justice, and cruel-hearted, I am no murderer, nor sacrilegious man, whom thou thus ill-usest; but a defender of the law.
I lighten my suffering by the pleasures which are connected with virtue.

11.text: I intend not, O tyrant, to get excused from the torment which is in behalf of virtue.
I have come of my own accord, that by the death of me, you may owe heavenly vengeance a punishment for more crimes.
O thou hater of virtue and of men, what have we done that thou thus revellest in our blood?
A great favour thou bestowest upon us, O tyrant, by enabling us to manifest our adherence to the law by means of nobler sufferings.
I am indeed younger than my brothers, but in understanding I am as old;
I, too, bearing with me a great avenger, O deviser of tortures, and enemy of the truly pious.

12.text: I call upon the of my fathers to be merciful to my race.

14.text: O reasonings more royal than a king, and freer than freemen!
O holy seven of harmonious brethren! for as the seven days of creation, about religion,

15.text: O reasoning of the sons, lord over the passions, and religion more desirable to a mother than progeny!

O in what way can I describe ethically the affections of parents toward their children, the resemblance of soul and of form engrafted into the small type of a child in a wonderful manner, especially through the greater sympathy of mothers with the feelings of those born of them!
O holy nature and parental feeling, and reward of bringing up children, and unconquerable maternal affection!
O thou mother, who wast tried at this time with bitterer pangs than those of parturition!
O thou only woman who hast brought forth perfect holiness!
O mother of a nation, avenger of the law, and defender of religion, and prime bearer in the battle of the affections!
O thou nobler in endurance than males, and more manly than men in patience!

16.text: I have proved, then, that not only men have obtained the mastery of their passions, but also that a woman despised the greatest torments.
O seven useless childbirths, and seven profitless periods of labour, and fruitless givings of suck, and miserable nursings at the breast.
O woman, soldier of for religion, thou, aged and a female, hast conquered through endurance even a tyrant; and though but weak, hast been found more powerful in deeds and words.
O sons, noble is the contest; to which you being called as a witness for the nation, strive zealously for the laws of your country.

17.text: O thou mother, who together with seven children didst destroy the violence of the tyrant, and render void his wicked intentions, and exhibit the nobleness of faith!

18.text: O children, descendants of the seed of , obey this law, and in every way be religious.

O that bitter, and yet not bitter, day when the bitter tyrant of the , quenching fire with fire in his cruel caldrons, brought with boiling rage the seven sons of the daughter of to the catapelt, and to all his torments!
